name: Saint-Chamond (Late)
description: Final mass produced version of the Saint-Chamond heavy tank.

INFORMATIONS.Name: Saint-Chamond (Late)
INFORMATIONS.Manufacturer: Compagnie des forges et aciéries de la marine et d'Homécourt (FAMH)

USERS.Description: Primary operator. France used this model alongside earlier variants to break through German trenches.

specifications.SERVICE:
The late-production model of the Saint-Chamond heavy breakthrough tank entered service in the latter half of 1917 as the final major refinement of the original design. Produced by the Compagnie des forges et aciéries de la marine et d’Homécourt (FAMH), this version incorporated all existing mid-series improvements while introducing a new, elevated commander’s cupola to address the chronic visibility issues experienced by earlier crews. Though the basic hull architecture and long frontal overhang remained unchanged, these alterations improved battlefield awareness, coordination, and overall handling in combat conditions.

In its operational role, the Saint-Chamond (Late) continued to function as a mobile gun platform intended to break through fortified trench systems. It retained the 75 mm field gun introduced in the Saint-Chamond (Mid), adapted from the French Mle 1897, which provided exceptional firepower for engaging enemy strongpoints, dugouts, machine-gun nests, and defensive emplacements from a protected firing position. The four Hotchkiss machine guns maintained the vehicle’s ability to defend against infantry threats at close range, allowing it to support advancing troops during combined-arms assaults.

The mechanical limitations of the design—short tracks relative to hull length, a sensitive suspension, and poor weight distribution—remained present, but late-production vehicles benefited from incremental fine-tuning and more reliable component assemblies. Their appliqué armour plate brought the effective frontal thickness to 18 mm, offering improved resistance to small-arms fire, shrapnel, and early anti-tank rifles, though these weapons could still penetrate the armour at short distances or favourable angles.

During 1917 and 1918, the Saint-Chamond (Late) served alongside the early and mid models in major French operations, often deployed in mixed formations. Although still hampered by mobility problems in heavily cratered terrain, the late variant’s improved observation capabilities made it more effective in coordinating fire, spotting targets, and adjusting aim under combat pressure. As the conflict shifted toward more mobile operations in 1918 and German positions began to collapse, its powerful long-range gun allowed it to remain tactically relevant as a direct-fire assault weapon, extending the operational usefulness of the Saint-Chamond line even as more advanced tank designs entered service.
